title: This principle will need some qualifications to protect it from easy counterexamples. For instance, if Q is a necessary truth, then P entails Q no matter what Q is, yet it is not apparently the case that, by knowing that the sky is blue, I am justified in believing Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem. We can avoid this problem by restricting the application of the principle to contingent propositions. We can further qualify the principle by restricting it to cases in which S is able to see that P entails Q
